description.en: The course will examine key thinkers who have contributed to philosophical reflections on time such as Augustine, Heidegger, Benjamin and Koselleck. We will ask how conceptions of time are related to temporal distinctions of modern and postmodern. Although the course is open to all students who have already taken some introductory course of philosophy, it is intended for upper-level students.
description.et: Õppeaine käigus loetakse aega käsitlevaid tekste võtmetähtsusega filosoofidelt nagu Augustinus, Heidegger, Benjamin ja Koselleck. Uurime, kuidas arusaamine aja mõistest on seotud modernismi ja postmodernismi ajalise piiritlemisega.

objectives.en:
The course aims to familiarise students with the philosophy of time and history within continental philosophy.

Students will also develop the following skills:

Self-Management Skills - time management, goal setting and self-motivation.

Academic skills - reading academic texts, academic writing and critical thinking.

People skills - how to communicate and participate in team work.

These will be developed during the seminar with group work and include skills for debating and for writing a well structured paper in philosophy.
objectives.et: Aine eesmärk on tutvustada üliõpilastele tänapäeva kontinentaalset aja- ja ajaloofilosoofiat.

learning_outcomes.en: The learning outcomes are a firm understanding of philosophy of time and history within continental philosophy. Having passed the course, the student has also improved his or her ability to analyze philosophical texts, his or her presentations skills.
learning_outcomes.et: Aine läbinud üliõpilasel on selge arusaam tänapäeva kontinentaalsest aja- ja ajaloofilosoofiast. Ta on ka arendanud oma filosoofilise teksti analüüsimise oskust ning esitlusoskusi.

notes.et:
Topic: Historicity and crises

It is not uncommon to hear claims that this or that event is bound to change the way we perceive history. Such a change was expected at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic and is also discussed in relation to the ongoing climate change. The same talk about "the end of the end of history" or "the return of the past" was caused by the beginning of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. But what is "perception of history" anyway, and how can crises and major historical events influence it? In this course, we will study the concept of different types of historicity and how theorists explained its changes during epochal events - from the French Revolution and World War II to events of our day and the near future.

Planned course outcomes: Upon completion of this course, the student will be able to recall major theories of the studied branch of philosophy of history, as well as their aspects (remembering).
The student will also be able to demonstrate an understanding of the topic, compare the theories studied with each other, and identify their differences and possible applications (understanding).
The student will also gain the skill to critically analyze different theories in relation to each other and analyze both current and past historical events from the point of view of the material studied during the course (application).
In addition, the student will be able to demonstrate proficiency in presentation skills, communication skills, debate, academic writing, research, and independent sourcing (transferable skills).
Methods used in the seminar: discussion of the reading material, group analysis of case studies.

independent_work.et: Students are required to read the texts at home, to prepare one presentation and to write a paper.

description.et:
Active participation. 
Assessment: the student has missed no more than two classes.

A presentation in class.
Assessment:
The student has presented once by the end of the course.
The presentation covers the main aspects of one of the studied theories.

An essay at the end of the course.
Assessment:
The essay is properly structured and written clearly.
In the essay, the student uses at least one of the studied theories as a basis for their research. 
In the essay, the student provides their own argument, elaborating on the chosen theory or applying it to a case study.
The student uses references to support the claims that are not their novel personal arguments.

All three criteria (seminar participation, presentation, essay) should be met in order to pass the course.

grade_preconditions.et: Active class participation (no more than two missed meetings), one presentation.

grade_evaluation.et: In order to pass the course, students are required to participate actively in the seminar, to make one presentation and to send a paper to the lecturer on time.

debt_elimination.et: To be arranged with the lecturer.
